data.title: Johan Botha
data.meta_description: One of Johan Botha’s teachers told him: “If you love music, music will love you back.” Throughout his relatively short career it was a maxim that this remarkable tenor with a powerful and rich voice
data.text:
One of Johan Botha’s teachers told him: “If you love music, music will love you back.” Throughout his relatively short career it was a maxim that this remarkable tenor with a powerful and rich voice always held to be true. He was fastidious to the point of perfectionism, travelling around the world with his own personal pianist-cum-coach who helped to prepare him for his performances. “When I’m doing Lohengrin, say, no other piece exists,” he once told Opera magazine. “If I don’t do it that way, I’ll make a complete balls-up of it.”

Botha was a singer of considerable stature, both vocally and physically. Hugh Canning wrote in The Sunday Times of his appearance in Wagner’s Tannhäuser in 2010: “His carnal obsession seems gastronomic, rather
